summary:
Propositions are statements about factual states of nature.

Propositions are statements about non-factual states of nature.

When evaluating forensic evidence, propositions are used to frame facts-in-issue.

When evaluating forensic evidence, propositions are used to describe measurable features of the evidence.

When evaluating forensic evidence, propositions are used to specify background information only.

Exhaustive propositions cover all set of possible outcomes for an event in question.

Exhaustive propositions have no logical overlap of possible outcomes for an event in question.

Mutually exclusive propositions have no logical overlap of possible outcomes for an event in question.

Mutually exclusive propositions cover all set of possible outcomes for an event in question.

Offence level propositions make a direct assertion about criminal liability.

Offence level propositions make an assertion about the source of a questioned sample.

Offence level propositions make an assertion about an activity having taken place.

Activity level propositions make an assertion about an activity having taken place.

Activity level propositions make an assertion about the source of a questioned sample.

Activity level propositions make a direct assertion about criminal liability.

Source level propositions make an assertion about the source of a questioned sample.

Source level propositions make a direct assertion about criminal liability.

Source level propositions make an assertion about an activity having taken place.

Propositions define the probative value of the evidence.

Propositions have little impact on the probative value of the evidence.

Probative value of the evidence does not depend on propositions.

Probative value of the evidence is the same for each proposition level in the hierarchy or propositions.

The prosecutor's fallacy occurs when the probability for the evidence conditioned on a proposition is mistaken for the probability of the proposition conditioned on the evidence.

The prosecutor's fallacy occurs when the probability for the evidence conditioned on a proposition is mistaken for the probability of the proposition.

The prosecutor's fallacy occurs when the probability for the evidence conditioned on a proposition is mistaken for the probability of the evidence.

The prosecutor's fallacy occurs when the probability for the evidence is mistaken for the probability of the proposition.
